title: Business News:  Valve Issue Delayed Launch of Boeing's Starliner  ----  By Micah Maidenberg and Doug Cameron
text:
Boeing Co.'s planned Starliner flight was postponed after engineers found a problem with some valves on a propulsion system used on the space capsule, the company and National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.

Boeing and NASA didn't specify when they would again attempt to launch the Starliner -- which was due to travel to the International Space Station without crew -- after saying teams need more time to understand what happened with the valves.

NASA said some of them weren't in proper configuration for the launch, which was scheduled for Aug. 3. Engineering teams have ruled out several potential causes of the problem, including software, the agency said.

The high-profile flight was meant as a do-over for Boeing, after the Starliner failed to reach the space station in a previous test flight in late 2019 due to software errors and following other delays. The botched mission a year and a half ago dented the record of a company that has been at the forefront of U.S. space exploration, including the Apollo missions to the moon.

Last week, officials from NASA said a preflight review of the launch had gone smoothly. The agency had wanted to test the Starliner without crew members on board ahead of a planned launch with astronauts later the year.

"We're going to let the data lead our work," John Vollmer, a Boeing vice president who is overseeing the Starliner program, said.
